name: Haitian Mac and Cheese
ingredients: 1/3 cup sliced red and yellow bell peppers
instructions: Melt butter in skillet over medium heat. Add onions and sauté for 1-2 mins.
Add bell peppers and cook 3-4 mins until tender.
Add garlic and sauté 1-2 mins until fragrant. Remove from heat.
Preheat oven to 350°F and grease a baking dish with butter.
Cook pasta in salted water as per package. Drain and return to hot pot.
Stir in cooked veggies, evaporated milk, mayonnaise, Gouda, and Parmesan. Season with salt and pepper.
Transfer mixture to baking dish and top with extra cheese.
Bake for 20–25 mins until golden. Broil 2–3 mins if you want a crispy top.
Let cool 10 mins before serving.
notes: To make homemade evaporated milk: simmer 1.5 cups full-fat milk for 25–30 mins until reduced.
Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge for 3–4 days.
Reheat with a splash of milk or cream in microwave or stovetop.
Best enjoyed fresh – not ideal for making ahead.

name: Haitian-Style Spaghetti
instructions: Slice the sausage, onion, and bell pepper. Chop parsley and thyme. Mince garlic. Set all aside.
Cook the pasta al dente according to box instructions.
In a large pan over medium heat, cook the sausage. Remove and set aside.
In the same pan, add bell pepper, half the onions, and garlic. Cook for 1 minute, stirring constantly.
Add tomato paste and 1/4 cup pasta water to break it down. Add cooked sausage. Stir to combine.
Reduce heat to low. Add pasta, Haitian Epis, salt and pepper, parsley, thyme, and remaining pasta water. Mix well.
Cover and let cook for 2 minutes. Serve hot.
notes: Spaghetti, linguine, or vermicelli are best for this dish. Avoid angel hair pasta.
Use pasta water to add moisture and dissolve tomato paste.
Fresh herbs preferred, but dry herbs also work.

name: No-Fuss Avocado Onion Salad
ingredients: 3 medium ripe avocados, peeled and thinly sliced
1 large sweet onion, halved and thinly sliced
instructions: Arrange avocado and onion slices on a large platter.
In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, mustard, lemon juice, and honey.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad.
Serve immediately.
notes: Best served fresh—avoid storing for long as avocados brown quickly.
Great as a light side or refreshing appetizer.

name: Cuban Sandwich
instructions: Split the Cuban bread rolls lengthwise.
Spread mustard on both sides of each roll.
Layer ham, roasted pork, Swiss cheese, and pickles on the bottom half.
Close the sandwich and press firmly.
Butter the outside of the sandwich and grill on a panini press or skillet until golden and cheese melts.
Cut diagonally and serve hot.
notes: Traditional Cuban bread is best, but any crusty roll works.
The key is pressing the sandwich to compress the layers.
Serve with plantain chips for authenticity.

name: Authentic Choripán with Chimichurri
ingredients: Salt and black pepper to taste
instructions: For chimichurri: Mix parsley, oregano, garlic, vinegar, olive oil, red pepper flakes, salt, and pepper in a bowl. Let sit for 30 minutes.
Grill chorizo sausages until cooked through and slightly charred.
Split the bread rolls and toast them lightly.
Place a chorizo in each roll and top generously with chimichurri sauce.
Serve immediately while hot.
notes: Chimichurri can be made ahead and stored in the refrigerator for up to a week.
Traditional choripán uses Argentine chorizo, but any spicy sausage works.
Best served with a cold beer or mate.

name: Venezuelan Avocado Chicken Salad
ingredients: Salt and black pepper to taste
instructions: In a large bowl, combine shredded chicken and mashed avocados.
Add mayonnaise, sour cream, red onion, cilantro, lime juice, and garlic powder.
Mix well until all ingredients are combined.
Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Serve on lettuce leaves or as a sandwich filling.
notes: This salad is perfect for using leftover chicken.
The avocado adds creaminess and healthy fats.
Can be served as a main dish or as a filling for arepas.

name: Venezuelan Arepas
instructions: In a large bowl, mix cornmeal, warm water, salt, and vegetable oil.
Knead the dough for 3-5 minutes until smooth and pliable.
Let the dough rest for 10 minutes.
Divide dough into 8 equal portions and shape into balls.
Flatten each ball into a disc about 1/2 inch thick.
Heat a griddle or skillet over medium heat and grease with butter or oil.
Cook arepas for 5-7 minutes on each side until golden brown and cooked through.
Split open and fill with your favorite ingredients.
notes: Pre-cooked white cornmeal (harina PAN) is essential for authentic arepas.
Arepas can be filled with cheese, meat, beans, or any combination.
Leftover arepas can be reheated in a toaster or oven.
